I am not an architect nor a contractor or engineer.

But over decades as a government employee, have seen architects fail to specify--and pay attention to the absolute need for--details that common sense would require. Examples: sinks in a student art studio? Signals along a commuter rail line? Sometimes I think some designers live in bubbles.

If they spent some time in similar spaces, maybe scrubbing floors (try Union Square station...) and other duties that would give them first-hand knowledge, the final results would both LOOK good, and WORK well too. Where will the garbage be stored until taken away? Are the hand rails narrow enough for a child or an arthritic elder? And what about their height? Can you navigate that escalator with hands full of Holiday shopping?

Real world design--those that do the commissioning should be required to understand that--attention, PATH board!

This is outrageous misinformation. I have a new ACA plan with Blue Shield. Blue Shield is paying providers in all ACA plans 10-30% less than their already low fees. The reason Kaiser patients are not complaining is because patients who had complaints have switched to another insurance plan. I was one of those patients who felt very restricted by my choices at Kaiser and got out ASAP.

I wish the NYTimes would stop giving this man a platform to spout this nonsense.

There is no negotiation on fees with providers. I am a provider myself as well as a chronically ill patient so I know how the system works from both angles to screw over both patient and provider. The insurance companies are the ones who profit at the expense of both patient and provider.

The networks have nothing to do with quality or efficiency. It's simply who will accept the insurance company's low fees.

Just to clarify a few things:

*Dr. GDNP is a radiologist who argued a thesis in microbio. He seems to be a good specialist in his field, but is by no means a public health expert. I would like to see these claims evaluated by a nicotine addiction expert (who, by the way, does not need to possess a medical license. MPHs are also good at what they do). If the NYT writes on the front cover that e-cigs are worrying experts, they must have evidence other than a few improperly designed CDC surveys. There is no clear evidence presented (except that, gee, teens like hookah flavor, sometimes with nicotine).

*Bringing up prescription narcotics is a distraction from the issue at hand. Opioids are very different than nicotine -- in mechanism, addictive potential, negative effects, and phenomenological experience. I acknowledge the issues with oxy, hydro, and heroin, and a large part of my point is that we should remain focused on these more dangerous and problematic drugs rather than get distracted by moral panic and "saving the children."

*I am not a libertarian. However, I am also not a DARE officer. I believe in making policy decisions based on clear evidence from well-designed studies.

*I've seen how awful cigarettes are. You'll never find me at a smokers' rights convention. I've never taken one puff. I have tried a hookah pen once, but it was nothing to write home about. I do know many who used e-cigs to quit smoking (including two teens).

A perfect example of how the welfare state perpetuates itself - that's the welfare-for-government-bureaucracies state, BTW.  As tobacco use falls, tobacco products are sold in fewer places and the regulators' workloads start shrinking, here they come with an expanding family of new products the government must examine, evaluate, experiment with, and fund studies and hold conferences in tourist destinations and regulate every way from Sunday.  And through it all, facts are irrelevant, even unwelcome.  Just make the funding request sound plausible and it's clear sailing 'til retirement - and their pension plans are secure.

My husband has worked in drug discovery (biotech, pharma, etc.) for over 15 years, and he seems bitter that these things can be administered to humans without any kind of safety trial, given that everything he does requires clinical trials.  "Has anyone smoked bannana flavor before -- how do we know it is even safe?" he asks.  It seems reasonable.  People are inhaling all kinds of untested compounds, with no data on what long term use might cause.  Recall that microwave popcorn butter has caused serious issues in factory workers that inhaled the fumes.  The buttered popcorn vaporizer might be an unhealthy idea, but what would prevent me from selling them?

I take issue w/ the statement that "To watch a feature film is to be immersed in its world..."  I don't find that to be true of either movies or t.v., only of books.  I can feel chilly on a hot day when a book takes place on a winter day, be surprised that it's daytime when I've been reading about the night, for example, neither of which happens w/ the visual media.  I also disagree w/ the idea that "novelists... would do well to bear in mind the novel's weirdness."  Give me well developed characters & plots w/ grace notes of place & atmosphere any day.

Private management experience does not prepare one for leadership of a nation's foreign policy. That is not the solution. I suppose FDR was probably our most successful president in terms of foreign policy, and he was so because he'd been undersecretary and secretary of the Navy, because he understood geopolitical power struggles, and the levers of government. I'm perfectly irritated by Obama's frequent shortcomings in the field but there's no reason to believe a Romney would have done any better. His white papers on FP were garbage.
